case_vignette: A 16-year-old Caucasian boy presents to your family practice office complaining of itchiness. He denies other symptoms. He also denies tobacco, alcohol, or other illicit drug use and is not sexually active. He has no other significant past medical or surgical history aside from a meniscal repair from a wrestling injury sustained two years ago from which he has recovered fully. Vitals are T 98.3, HR 67, BP 110/70. On exam you note several pruritic, erythematous, slightly raised annular patches with central clearing on his back.
question: Which  additional tests or features are sufficient to make the diagnosis of this boy's skin lesion?
correct_ans: presence of hyphae when koh added to skin scrapings

Is this itchiness accompanied by a rash?

trial_3.summarized_frq:
Based on the given symptoms, consider testing for: 1. Syphilis (dark field microscopy or rapid plasma reagin test), 2. Herpes simplex virus (PCR or viral culture), 3. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV test), 4. Scabies (skin scraping), 5. Fungal infection (KOH preparation or culture), 6. Allergic reaction (patch test), 7. Pityriasis rosea (clinical diagnosis). 

Features that may support the diagnosis of some of these conditions include: 
- Syphilis: Systemic symptoms, lymphadenopathy, mucocutaneous lesions
- Herpes simplex virus: Vesicles or ulcers, prodromal symptoms (tingling, burning, itching)
- Human immunodeficiency virus: Weight loss, fever, night sweats, lymphadenopathy
- Scabies: Burrows, pruritus, rash in intertriginous areas
- Fungal infection: Satellite lesions, scaling, erythema
